page.title: 03CLEE HILL DIALECT
page.content:
Men from the Black Country, Gloucestershire, Herefordshire, Wales, Worcestershire, Nottinghamshire, Yorkshire and Scotland came to the {Clee Hill}area in the 19th. century to work in the lime and stone quarries, and coalmines. The area was isolated and people didn't travel far.{The Clee {Hill Dialect}was formed by words from all of these areas. Today,{the Dialect can still be heard, but not as frequently as in the past. Below are some examples of{The Dialect.}
Clee Hill is known as{The Bonk. {Bist thee gooin wum?}means Are you going home? {I conna}means I can't. { {Hoss}means horse. {Yud}means head. { {Suck}means sweets. {Wench}means girl.{ {Shipp}means sheep. {Fut}means foot. { }
